abstract.p: Betsy Israel article on child rearing focuses on charms and perils of being mother of twins, triplets, quadruplets or quintuplets; photos (M)

block.p: Until about last week, I fully viewed myself as the mother of multiples. (I have two kids under 6, which feels like having four.) As it turns out, I was deluded. Talk to mothers of twins, triplets, quadruplets, quintuplets, and they will (sort of) smile. Then they will suggest that I, a mere mother of ''singletons,'' don't have a clue. We may all be moms but we do not belong to the same national chapter of motherhood.

Until about last week, I fully viewed myself as the mother of multiples. (I have two kids under 6, which feels like having four.) As it turns out, I was deluded. Talk to mothers of twins, triplets, quadruplets, quintuplets, and they will (sort of) smile. Then they will suggest that I, a mere mother of ''singletons,'' don't have a clue. We may all be moms but we do not belong to the same national chapter of motherhood.

There are right now more twins, triplets and ''higher order'' multiples than ever in history. The numbers: since 1980, twin births in the United States have increased 42 percent while triplet, quad and other multiple births have risen 272 percent. The primary reason: fertility drugs. But attention paid to ''medical miracles'' like the McCaughey Seven of Des Moines obscures the very real complexities of multiple motherhood: serious illness, endless expense and the daily anarchy of life with 4 or so kids who seem like 10. Rineke Dijkstra is an Amsterdam-based photographer. Betsy Israel wrote about Amy Fisher for the magazine in July 1996.
